plant_translocations.content: A laboratory study was undertaken to investigate the leaf systemic properties and the translaminar aphicidal activity of two commercialised neonicotinoid (chloronicotinyl) insecticides. For that purpose [14C]imidacloprid was subjected to uptake and translocation studies in cabbage and cotton after foliar application. Foliar penetration and short-term translocation patterns of imidacloprid were similar in both plant species. Nevertheless imidacloprid penetrated twice as much into cabbage leaves as it did into cotton leaves. It showed a comparable translaminar behaviour and was entirely translocated acropetally, indicating its well-known xylem mobility. The translaminar and acropetal movement of imidacloprid and acetamiprid were quantified by simple laboratory bioassays using the green peach aphid, Myzus persicae (Sulzer), and the cotton aphid, Aphis gossypii (Glover), as typical homopteran pests for cabbage and cotton, respectively. A single dose (7.5 micrograms AI per leaf) applied to the upper leaf surface of cabbage and cotton was tested against aphids feeding on the lower leaf surface both close to and distant from the site of application 1, 5 and 12 days after treatment. The translaminar residual activity of imidacloprid on cabbage leaves was superior to that of acetamiprid, whereas its translaminar efficacy against A gossypii on cotton was inferior to that of acetamiprid. However, oral ingestion bioassays using an artificial double membrane feeding system revealed no significant differences in intrinsic activity between the two neonicotinoids tested.
plant_translocations.reference: Buchholz, A., & Nauen, R. (2002). Translocation and translaminar bioavailability of two neonicotinoid insecticides after foliar application to cabbage and cotton. Pest Management Science: Formerly Pesticide Science, 58(1), 10-16.

method.Plant Grown Condition: Savoy cabbage, Brassica oleracea sabauda Lcv 'Fischenicher Advent', and cotton, Gossypium hirsutum L cvStoneville 474’,were cultivated under greenhouseconditions at 22'C and 65% RH under a 16:8 hlight:dark photoperiod and were artifcially illuminated by sodium vapour lamps (400W) if ambient light intensity dropped below 35000 lux(630μE m**-2 S**-1). The plants were watered daily by a special feece irrigation technique. Plants with two nearly fully expanded true leaves and a third true leaf having aquarter of its final size were used for the translocation experiments and the systemic bioassay.
method.Chemical Preparation: Radiolabelled (4.64 MBq/mg ) was of analytical grade (purity>99%). Unlabelled imidacloprid and acetamiprid were obtained in-house and of highest purity available, ie at least 97%.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Two droplets (5 ul each. 400-450 ng 14C-labelled Al) of the laboratory formulation were applied to the upper side of the frsttrue leaf of cotton and cabbage plants (three replicates) on designated application sites marked with a pen. The water of the applied droplets evaporated within 1 hour of application. 'Residue' refers to the amount of active ingredient removed from the site of application by cellulose acetate stripping

plant_translocations.content: A laboratory study was undertaken to investigate the leaf systemic properties and the translaminar aphicidal activity of two commercialised neonicotinoid (chloronicotinyl) insecticides. For that purpose [14C]imidacloprid was subjected to uptake and translocation studies in cabbage and cotton after foliar application. Foliar penetration and short-term translocation patterns of imidacloprid were similar in both plant species. Nevertheless imidacloprid penetrated twice as much into cabbage leaves as it did into cotton leaves. It showed a comparable translaminar behaviour and was entirely translocated acropetally, indicating its well-known xylem mobility. The translaminar and acropetal movement of imidacloprid and acetamiprid were quantified by simple laboratory bioassays using the green peach aphid, Myzus persicae (Sulzer), and the cotton aphid, Aphis gossypii (Glover), as typical homopteran pests for cabbage and cotton, respectively. A single dose (7.5 micrograms AI per leaf) applied to the upper leaf surface of cabbage and cotton was tested against aphids feeding on the lower leaf surface both close to and distant from the site of application 1, 5 and 12 days after treatment. The translaminar residual activity of imidacloprid on cabbage leaves was superior to that of acetamiprid, whereas its translaminar efficacy against A gossypii on cotton was inferior to that of acetamiprid. However, oral ingestion bioassays using an artificial double membrane feeding system revealed no significant differences in intrinsic activity between the two neonicotinoids tested.
plant_translocations.reference: Buchholz, A., & Nauen, R. (2002). Translocation and translaminar bioavailability of two neonicotinoid insecticides after foliar application to cabbage and cotton. Pest Management Science: Formerly Pesticide Science, 58(1), 10-16.

method.Plant Grown Condition: Savoy cabbage, Brassica oleracea sabauda Lcv 'Fischenicher Advent', and cotton, Gossypium hirsutum L cvStoneville 474’,were cultivated under greenhouseconditions at 22'C and 65% RH under a 16:8 hlight:dark photoperiod and were artifcially illuminated by sodium vapour lamps (400W) if ambient light intensity dropped below 35000 lux(630μE m**-2 S**-1). The plants were watered daily by a special feece irrigation technique. Plants with two nearly fully expanded true leaves and a third true leaf having aquarter of its final size were used for the translocation experiments and the systemic bioassay.
method.Chemical Preparation: Radiolabelled (4.64 MBq/mg ) was of analytical grade (purity>99%). Unlabelled imidacloprid and acetamiprid were obtained in-house and of highest purity available, ie at least 97%.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Spared on the upper side (three droplets of 5 ul, each containing 2.5μg Al).Translaminar efficacy determined from the mortality (±SD) of aphids feeding close to the application sites, and 'acropetal' efficacy from the mortality (±SD) of aphids feeding distant from the application sites.  The water of the applied droplets evaporated within 1 hour of application.

plant_translocations.content: Uptake and translocation of imidacloprid (IMI), thiamethoxam (THX) and difenoconazole (DFZ) in rice plants (Oryza sativa L.) were investigated with a soil-treated experiment at two application rates: field rate (FR) and 10FR under laboratory conditions. The dissipation of the three compounds in soil followed the first-order kinetics and DFZ showed greater half-lives than IMI and THX. Detection of the three compounds in rice tissues indicated that rice plants could take up and accumulate these pesticides. The concentrations of IMI and THX detected in leaves (IMI,10.0 and 410 mg/kg dw; THX, 23.0 and 265 mg/kg dw) were much greater than those in roots (IMI,1.37 and 69.3 mg/kg dw; THX, 3.19 and 30.6 mg/kg dw), which differed from DFZ. The DFZ concentrations in roots (15.6 and 79.1 mg/kg dw) were much greater than those in leaves (0.23 and 3.4 mg/kg dw). The bioconcentration factor (BCF), representing the capability of rice to accumulate contaminants from soil into plant tissues, ranged from 1.9 to 224.3 for IMI, from 2.0 to 72.3 for THX, and from 0.4 to 3.2 for DFZ at different treated concentrations. Much higher BCFs were found for IMI and THX at 10FR treatment than those at FR treatment, however, the BCFs of DFZ at both treatments were similar. The translocation factors (TFs), evaluating the capability of rice to translocate contaminants from the roots to the aboveground parts, ranged from 0.02 to 0.2 for stems and from 0.02 to 9.0 for leaves. The tested compounds were poorly translocated from roots to stems, with a TF below 1. However, IMI and THX were well translocated from roots to leaves. Clothianidin (CLO), the main metabolite of THX, was detected at the concentrations from 0.02 to 0.5 mg kg 1 in soil and from 0.07 to 7.0 mg kg 1 inplants. Concentrations of CLO in leaves were almost 14 times greater than those in roots at 10*FR treatment.
plant_translocations.reference: Ge, J., Cui, K., Yan, H., Li, Y., Chai, Y., Liu, X., … Yu, X. (2017). Uptake and translocation of imidacloprid, thiamethoxam and difenoconazole in rice plants. Environmental Pollution, 226, 479–485. doi:10.1016/j.envpol.2017.04.043

method.Test Plant: Rice (Oryza sativa L. ssp. japonica cvs. Nanjing 9108)
method.Plant Grown Condition: Greenhouse (humidity 60%) with temperature of 25°C day/18°C night and supplemental lighting of 300 W/m2 from 8:00 to 22:00 daily. Plants were watered daily with 300 mL water to keep them well-watered but not flooded.
method.Chemical Preparation: Certified pesticide standards of IMI (99.5%), THX (99%), DFZ (99%) and CLO (99%) were purchased from Dr. Ehrenstorfer (Germany). Imidacloprid (IMI), Thiamethoxam (THX), and Difenoconazole (DFZ) were first dissolved in acetonitrile and then added into the soil separately to make the initial concentrations approximate 1 mg IMI/kg soil,10 mg IMI/kg soil, 1 mg THX/kg soil, 10mg THX/kg soil, 2 mg DFZ/kg soil and 20 mg DFZ/kg soil, respectively.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: IMI: 1 mg/kg soil (field rate, FR) and 10 mg/kg soil (10FR). THX: 1 mg/kg soil (FR) and 10 mg/kg soil (10FR). DFZ: 2 mg/kg soil (FR) and 20 mg/kg soil (10*FR).
method.Other Information: 25 containers (each with 20 rice seedlings) for each pesticide treatment level. Soil and plant samples were collected in triplicates at different time points.

plant_translocations.content: Brown root rot disease (BRRD), caused by Phellinus noxius, is a significant tree disease in tropical and subtropical regions. To enhance the chemical control of BRRD and prevent the emergence of fungicide resistance in P. noxius, this study examined the control efficacy and systemic activity of fungicides with various modes of action. Fourteen fungicides with different modes of action were tested for their inhibitory effects on 39 P. noxius isolates from multiple regions. Cyproconazole, epoxiconazole, and tebuconazole (target-site G1) exhibited colony growth inhibition of P. noxius by 99.9% to 100% at 10 ppm and 97.7% to 99.8% at 1 ppm. Another effective fungicide was cyprodinil + fludioxonil (target-site D1 + E2), which showed growth inhibition of 96.9% at 10 ppm and 88.6% at 1 ppm. Acropetal translocation of six selected fungicides was evaluated in bishop wood (Bischofia javanica) seedlings, with cyproconazole and tebuconazole being the most efficiently absorbed by roots and transported acropetally. Greenhouse experiments indicated that cyproconazole, tebuconazole, and epoxiconazole have slightly higher potential for controlling BRRD compared to mepronil, prochloraz, and cyprodinil + fludioxonil. Since all tested fungicides lacked basipetal translocation, soil drenching should be considered over trunk injection for their use in BRRD control.
plant_translocations.reference: Liao, T. Z., Chen, Y. H., Tsai, J. N., Chao, C., Huang, T. P., Hong, C. F., ... & Chung, C. L. (2023). Translocation of fungicides and their efficacy in controlling Phellinus noxius, the cause of brown root rot disease. Plant Disease, 107(7), 2039-2053.

method.Test Plant: Bischofia javanica (bishop wood seedlings), 6-12 months old used due to abundant roots, tender tissues, high susceptibility
method.Plant Grown Condition: Maintained at 35°C day/30°C night, 55-95% RH in phytotron. Under natural light. Leaves trimmed to 3-5 trifoliate leaves per plant before assays
method.Chemical Preparation: Root immersion - 100 ppm solutions of fungicides. Stem injection - Stock solutions ranging 75,000-625,000 ppm injected at 3 μL
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Acropetal - 5 root tips immersed in 50 mL fungicide solution. Bidirectional - 3 μL fungicide stock injected into stem
method.Other Information: Sampling at 7 and 21 days after treatment. Plant dissected into 5 cm segments (roots, stems, leaves). Fungicide concentrations measured by LC/GC-MS/MS. 2 independent trials with 6 plants per treatment (3 per timepoint)

plant_translocations.content: We conducted uptake experiments with 12 different organic chemicals using 16 plant species and observed variations in their ability to take up and translocate these chemicals. The shoot and root concentrations of each chemical varied among the plant species. Root concentration factor values increased with an increasing log of the n-octanol-water partition coefficient (log Kow) of the organic chemicals, suggesting that root concentrations may be predicted to some extent based on log Kow. Root-to-shoot translocation was also related to log Kow, as the shoot-to-root concentration ratio decreased with increasing log Kow. However, the relationship between shoot concentration factor value and log Kow was not clear and differed among plant species.
plant_translocations.reference: Namiki, S., Otani, T., Motoki, Y., Seike, N., & Iwafune, T. (2018). Differential uptake and translocation of organic chemicals by several plant species from soil. Journal of pesticide science, 43(2), 96-107.

method.Test Plant: Hordeum distichon, Zea mays L., Glycine max Merrill, Phaseolus vulgaris L., Brassica oleracea L. var. capitata, Brassica rapa L. war. peruviridis, Chrysanthemum coronarium L., Lactuca sativa L., Allissms wakegi Araki, Apium graveolens L. war. dulce, Solanum lycopersicum Mill., Capsicum grossism, Cucumtis sativis L., Cucurbita maxima Duch., Spinacia oleracea L., and Beta vulgaris L. var. cicla.
method.Plant Grown Condition: Seeds germinated in nursery soil in growth chamber at 20°C, 14:10 hr light:dark cycle. Seedlings transplanted at 7-28 days into test soil pots and grown for 21 more days under same conditions. Soil moisture maintained at 50-70% water holding capacity (WHC).
method.Chemical Preparation: 12 organic chemicals (10 pesticides, β-HCH, dieldrin) with log Kow -0.6 to 5 dissolved in acetone at 50 mg/L. 1 L mixture added to 278g Celite powder, acetone evaporated leaving 92.6-133.6 μg/g of each chemical on Celite.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: 450g uncontaminated soil mixed with 5g chemical-loaded Celite in 600 mL pots. Fertilized with chemical fertilizer and dolomite. Final concentrations ranged 81.0-129.7 μg/pot.
method.Other Information: Plants grown to obtain 1-2g root dry weight per species. At 21 days, shoots and roots harvested, fresh weights measured, divided into subsamples to determine moisture content and chemical concentrations.
